conclusion: To solve the problem, I will calculate the induced electromotive force (EMF) using the area and angular velocity of the wire frame. Then, I will determine the instantaneous and average induced current based on the resistance and EMF.

The image shows a rectangular wire frame abcd rotating in a uniform horizontal magnetic field. The frame has a fixed vertical axis of rotation along cd. The magnetic induction intensity is B, the area of the frame is S, and the resistance is R.
The area of the wire frame is S, and it rotates at an angular velocity ω.

premise: The area of the wire frame is S, and it rotates at an angular velocity ω.
conclusion: The induced electromotive force (EMF) is given by EMF = S ω B.

premise: The induced electromotive force (EMF) is given by EMF = S ω B.
conclusion: When the frame rotates through an angle of 60°, the EMF becomes EMF = S ω B = S ω B · 60/360 = 1/6 S ω B.

premise: The EMF becomes EMF = 1/6 S ω B.
conclusion: The instantaneous induced current i is given by Ohm's law: i = EMF/R = 1/6 S ω B/R.

premise: The EMF becomes EMF = 1/6 S ω B.
conclusion: The average induced EMF over the 60° rotation is 1/6 S ω B.

premise: The average induced EMF over the 60° rotation is 1/6 S ω B.
conclusion: The average induced current i_avg is given by: i_avg = EMF_avg/R = 1/6 S ω B/R.

The instantaneous value of the induced current is 1/6 S ω B/R. During the process, the average value of the induced electromotive force is 1/6 S ω B. The average value of the induced current is 1/6 S ω B/R.
